pageContext.claim: “We are keeping the name Fort Bragg, you do know that, right?  They want cancel culture, you know? We won two World Wars out of Fort Bragg and we have other forts. We're keeping it....It's our culture. It's our heritage. So many victories, so many victories out of Fort Bragg.”
pageContext.analysis: At the time Trump made this comment, the Senate had already passed a bill that would have started the process of removing the names of Confederate military figures from U.S. bases, including Braxton Bragg, a former U.S. Army artillery commander and West Point graduate who later fought for the Confederacy during the Civil War. Trump later vetoed the bill but his veto was overturned by large bipartisan majorities.
